content: "To mitigate the difficulty":  this "mitigate" doesn't reduce the difficulty of the main problem. In the worst case you have to go through all the possible combination to answer the question. Whether to record weight per bins is marginal issue. I'm noting this because I spent days trying to figure out how to solve this problem without brute-force.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good luck hope you enjoy Hong-Kong !

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun puzzle if you want to work on optimization, might be on the harder side of 'medium' puzzle but I think it's the right difficulty level.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I accept the contribution because it is well defined, difficult enough and I had have fun working on my solution.

Love to play this. Perhaps a little bit harder than medium level.

Maybe, the output can be reduced from yes|no per line to the number of positive cases (yes) overall.

Goal
* Please change "a NP-hard" to "an NP-hard".

Input
* Line 1: Please add "for the number of test cases".

Output
* Please change "m lines" to "n lines".

* Please format "yes" and "no" as {{constants}}.

Constraints
* Suggest to change "each item's weight" to "[[w1]] [[w2]] [[w3]] ... [[wm]]".

Thanks.

Glad that you like this puzzle. The difficulty level is somewhat between Hard and Medium. I'm ready to put it to Hard if there are more voices tell me to do this.

The output format is a serial of yes and no. It is a binary sequence that can easily be brute force hacked if the list is too short. By using a count to replace the sequence will reduce its anti-hackability. (People can submit a hundred times by hardcode or random output to bingo.)
